patterns.pattern: First-time contributors (0 prior PRs) have significantly lower merge rates than established contributors, especially in non-critical categories
XS and S size labels correlate with higher merge rates (~26-30%) regardless of author history
Top-tier categories (agents, gateway, commands) have higher baseline merge rates and can partially compensate for weak author credentials
Security and critical path fixes (authorization, validation, session management) receive preferential treatment despite author history
Low merge rate authors (5+ prior PRs with <5% merge rate) are strong negative predictors of future merges, even in favorable categories
Missing critical feature data (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) increases prediction uncertainty and tends toward conservative (negative) predictions
Documentation category PRs have lower merge rates than feature/fix categories and require stronger compensatory signals
Large scope PRs (XL size, multiple categories, extensive LoC) are strong negative signals even with experienced authors
Established contributors (10+ prior PRs) with above-baseline merge rates (>20%) are reliable positive signals across most categories
Issue references and bug-fix classification provide specificity signals that improve merge likelihood
Maintainer and experience contributor labels are strong positive signals that can override weak author history
Test-focused PRs have stronger merge likelihood than equivalent non-test changes, especially from low-credibility authors
Multi-category/multi-channel touches indicate scope creep or misclassification and reduce merge likelihood without compensatory signals
